history.content:
Look at lectures from past semesters to get some intuition. I would say focus on that and maybe try going through some of the discussion and homework problems from the class

___

The above student's answer is great! I also suggest reading the course notes on eecs70.org; they are very comprehensive and well written. Also, try to relax as much as you can before the class starts! CS 70 is an intense (but interesting) class, and you'll want to make sure you're well rested before.

-----

I took 70 in the summer too, and I remember looking at the IMT Decal's notes before starting the class (much of it is on propositional logic and the relevant symbols and syntax). It definitely helped since over the summer they go over all of this in one lecture, and then it's on to proofs the next day. I would maybe look at the propositional logic notes from class or from the Decal, so that you don't get bogged down by all the new symbols and definitions immediately. Everything else in the class after that gets introduced a bit more in-depth (though yes, summer 70 is a bit of a storm of new concepts).

Look at lectures from past semesters to get some intuition. I would say focus on that and maybe try going through some of the discussion and homework problems from the class

___

Freshman here, taking CS70 over the summer. What are some of the best ways to prepare for the course in the few days leading up to the start of the course? I have a little over a month to prep, so I was wondering what material I should aim for.

For context, my math background is pretty sparse, but my fundamentals are strong. I have nearly no linear algebra experience.
history.subject: Best way to prep for CS70
